analyzed: sa śīrṣāṇi eva utkṛtya upādhatta atha itarāṇi kusindhāni apsu prāplāvayat ajena yajñam  samasthāpayan na id me yajñaḥ vikṛṣṭaḥ sat iti ātmā vai yajñaḥ na id me yama ātmā vikṛṣṭaḥ  sat iti etena paśunā iṣṭvā tat prajāpatiḥ apaśyat yathā etasya agneḥ antam na paryait
translated: He cut off the heads only and put them down; and the other parts he drowned in the water. With the goat he completed the sacrifice.🔽'Lest my sacrifice should be spoiled,'--the sacrifice is the self: 'lest my self should be spoiled,' he thought. Having performed the sacrifice with that (goat), Prajâpati saw that he had not reached the end of that (original) Agni.

original: sa aikṣata / yamimamātmānamapsu prāpiplavaṃ tamanvicānīti🔽tamanvaicattadyadeṣāmapsu praviddhānām pratyatiṣṭhattā apaḥ samabharadatha🔽yadasyāṃ tām mṛdaṃ tadubhayaṃ sambhṛtya mṛdaṃ
analyzed: sa aikṣata yam imam ātmānam apsu prāpiplavam tam anvicāni iti  tam anvaicat tat yat eṣām apsu praviddhānām pratyatiṣṭhat tāḥ apaḥ samabharat atha  yat asyām tām mṛdam tat ubhayam sambhṛtya mṛdam
translated: He saw (that the heads were the most valuable part of the victim),--'That body which I have drowned in the water, I will search out.'🔽He searched for it; and what remained of them when they were drowned in the water, that he collected together, and put it into the water.

analyzed: cāpaḥ ca iṣṭakām akarot sasmāt etat ubhayam iṣṭakāḥ bhavati mṛd ca āpaḥ ca
translated: And what there was of it in this (earth), having collected both together, he made it into clay and water, and fashioned bricks. For this reason these two things, the clay and the water, are (used) for making bricks.

original: sa aikṣata / yadi vā idamitthameva sadātmānamabhisaṃskaris pacānīti
analyzed: sa aikṣata yadi vai idam ittham eva sat ātmānam abhisaṃskariḥ pacāni iti
translated: He considered: 'If I were to make myself up in this way, as I am, I should be perishable.'

analyzed: tat agninā apacat tat enat amṛtam akarot etat vai haviḥ amṛye martya kuṇapo
translated: He cooked it with fire; that made it immortal. For this oblation is immortal, but a mortal corpse.

analyzed: na apahata pāpmā bhaviṣyāmi hanta etat agninā atam bhavati yat agninā pacanti
translated: 'I shall not be free from sin,' (he thought); 'well, it becomes that with fire, since they cook it with fire.'

analyzed: tasmāt agninā iṣṭakāḥ pacanti amṛtāḥ eva enāḥ tat kurvanti
translated: Therefore they cook the bricks with fire; they make them immortal.

analyzed: tat yat iṣṭvā paśunā apaśyat  tasmāt iṣṭakāḥ tasmāt iṣṭvā eva paśunā iṣṭakāḥ
translated: Now, because he saw the bricks after he had sacrificed with the animal,

original: kuryādaniṣṭakā ha tā bhavanti yāḥ purā paśoḥ kurvantyatho ha tadanyadeva / / /
analyzed: kuryāt aniṣṭakāḥ ha tāḥ bhavanti yāḥ purā paśoḥ kurvanti atha u ha tat anyat eva
translated: therefore one should make the bricks after he has sacrificed with the animal. Those are not bricks which they make before the animal; but then it is something else.

original: tadyāstāḥ śriyaḥ /🔽etāni tāni paśuśīrṣāṇyatha yāni tāni kusindhānyetāstāḥ pañca
analyzed: tat yāḥ tāḥ śriyaḥ  etāni tāni paśu śīrṣāṇi atha yāni tāni kusindhāni etāḥ tāḥ pañca
translated: Now, those which were the glories,🔽those are the animal heads; and those which were the pieces of wood, those are the five layers. In that he piles up the layers after putting on the animal heads,

analyzed: citayaḥ tat yat paśu śīrṣāṇi upadhāya citīḥ cinoti etaiḥ eva tacīrṣabhiḥ etāni kusindhāni  saṃdadhāti
translated: with those heads he joins those pieces of wood.

analyzed: te ete sarve paśavaḥ yat agniḥ
translated: Now, all these animals are what Agni is.

analyzed: tasmāt agnau paśavaḥ ramante
translated: Therefore animals delight in Agni.

analyzed: smin agniḥ ādhīyate
translated: In him Agni is piled up.

original: 'gnirhyeṣa yatpaśavastato vai prajāpataśubhireva tatpaśavo ramante tasmādyasya
analyzed: gniḥ hi eṣa yat paśavaḥ tatas vai prajāpata śubhiḥ eva tat paśavaḥ ramante tasmāt yasya
translated: For the cattle are Agni, and therefore the cattle delight themselves in the splendour of Prajapati. Therefore,

original: paśavo bhavanti tairagnirabhavat etairatra sarvaiḥ prajāpatirayakṣyata
analyzed: paśavaḥ bhavanti taiḥ agniḥ abhavat etaiḥ atra sarvaiḥ prajāpatiḥ ayakṣyata
translated: when one has cattle, by them Agni is satisfied. By these all here Prajapati will sacrifice.

analyzed: tat eva agneḥ antam par
translated: That is the end of Agni's (sacrifice).

analyzed: tat ha eke āhuḥ
translated: Here some say,

analyzed: atra eva etaiḥ sarvaiḥ paśubhiḥ yajeta yat vā ayaiṣyat tat yat etaiḥ atra
translated: 'Here he should sacrifice with all these cattle, since he will go to them.' If he were to sacrifice here with all these,

original: sarvairyajeta tadevāgnerantam parīyāditi na tathā kuryāddevānāṃ taditādiyādatho
analyzed: sarvaiḥ yajeta tat eva agneḥ antam parīyāt iti na tathā kuryāt devānām tat itāt iyāt atho
translated: he would reach the end of Agni's (sacrifice). He should not do so. He would go to the place of the gods,

original: pathastadiyādatho kiṃ tataḥ sambharedetāni vā etatkusindhānyetāścitīḥ sambharati
analyzed: pathaḥ tat iyāt atha u kim tatas sambharet etāni vai etat kusindhāni etāḥ citīḥ sambharati
translated: or to the path, or what would he collect from that? He collects these layers and these bricks.

analyzed: tasmāt tathā na kuryāt
translated: Therefore he should not do so.

analyzed: yat u eva etān paśūn ālabhate  āyatanam eva etat agnaye karoti na hi anāyatane kaścana
translated: And, again, as to why he seizes these victims.

original: ramate 'nnaṃ vā āyatanaṃ tadetatpurastānnidadhāti tadenam paśyannagnirupāvartate / / /
analyzed: ramate nnam vai āyatanam tat etat purastāt nidadhāti tat enam paśyan agniḥ upāvartate
translated: He makes this a resting-place for Agni, for nowhere does he delight so much as in a resting-place. A resting-place is food. He places it in front. Agni turns to it, seeing it.

analyzed: puruṣaḥ śvas gauḥ aviḥ ajaḥ bhavanti
translated: A man, a horse, a bull, a ram, and a gayal are (the victims).

analyzed: etāvantaḥ vai sarve paśavaḥ nnam
translated: So many are all the cattle, food.

analyzed: paśavaḥ tat yāvat annam tat etat purastāt nidadhāti tat enam paśyan agniḥ upāvartate
translated: As much food as there is, so much is that. He places it in front. Agni turns back, seeing it.

analyzed: pañca bhavanti
translated: They are five.

analyzed: pañca hi ete gnayāḥ yat etāḥ citayaḥ tebhyaḥ etat pañca āyatanāni nidadhāti
translated: For there are five of these fires, namely these layers. For them he places these five abodes.

analyzed: tat enam paśyan agniḥ upāvartate
translated: Agni turns back, seeing it.

original: tadyadagnibhya iti /🔽bahavo hyete 'gnayo yadetāścitayo 'tha yatkāmāyeti yathā taṃ
analyzed: tat yat agnibhyaḥ iti  bahavaḥ hi ete gnayaḥ yat etāḥ citayaḥ yat kāmāya iti yathā tam
translated: As to why (he places them) 'for the fires.'

analyzed: kāmam āpnuyāt yajamānaḥ yad kāmaḥ etat karma kurute
translated: For there are many of these fires, namely these layers. Then as to why (he places them) 'for such and such a wish.' As the sacrificer may obtain that wish for which he performs this rite, for that wish he performs this rite.

original: puruṣam prathamamālabhate /🔽puruṣo hi prathamaḥ paśūnāmathāśvam puruṣaṃ🔽hyanvaśvo 'tha gāmaśvaṃ hyanu gaurathāviṃ gāṃ hyanvavirathājamaviṃ
analyzed: puruṣam prathamam ālabhate  puruṣaḥ hi prathamaḥ paśūnām atha aśvam puruṣam  hi anu aśvaḥ tha gām aśvam hi anu gauḥ atha avim gām hi anu aviḥ atha ajam avim
translated: He slaughters the man first.

analyzed: hi anvajaḥ tat enān yathāpūrvam yathāśreṣṭham ālabhate
translated: For the man is the first of animals. Then the horse, for after the man comes the horse. Then the cow, for after the horse comes the cow. Then the sheep, for after the cow comes the sheep. Then the goat, for after the sheep comes the goat. Thus he slaughters them according to their order, according to their excellence.

analyzed: teṣām viṣamāḥ raśanāḥ syuḥ
translated: Their tethers should be of unequal length.

analyzed: puruṣasya varṣiṣṭhā atha hrasīyasī atha hrasīyasī
translated: The man's should be the longest, then shorter, then shorter still.

original: tadyathārūpam paśūnāṃ raśanāḥ karotyapapavasyasāya sarvāstveva samāḥ syuḥ sarvāḥ
analyzed: tat yathārūpam paśūnām raśanāḥ karoti apapavasyasāya sarvāḥ tu eva samāḥ syuḥ sarvāḥ
translated: Thus he makes the tethers according to the form of the animals, for the avoidance of confusion. But all should be of equal length, all of the same size.

original: sadṛśyaḥ sarve hyete samāḥ sarve sadṛśā agnayo hyucyante 'nnaṃ hyucyante tena
analyzed: sadṛśyaḥ sarve hi ete samāḥ sarve sadṛśāḥ agnayaḥ hi ucyante nnam hi ucyante tena
translated: For all these are equal, all are alike; the fires are called, the food is called, by that

analyzed: samāḥ tena sadṛśāḥ
translated: they are equal, by that they are alike.

original: tadāhuḥ / kathamasyaiṣo 'gniḥ pañceṣṭakaḥ sarvaḥ paśuṣvārabdhā bhavatīti
analyzed: tat āhuḥ katham asya eṣaḥ gniḥ pañca iṣṭakaḥ sarvaḥ paśuṣu ārabdhā bhavati iti

original: puroḍāśakapāleṣu nvevāpyata iyam prathamā mṛnmayīṣṭakātha yatpaśumālabhate
analyzed: puroḍāśa kapāleṣu nu eva apyate iyam prathamā mṛd mayī iṣṭakā atha yat paśum ālabhate

analyzed: tena paśu iṣṭakā āpyate yat vapām abhitas hiraṇya śakalau bhavataḥ tena
translated: by that the animal layer is put together. Then in that there are two pieces of gold on each side of the omentum,

translated: by that the gold layer is put together. Then in that there is fuel, the sacrificial post, and the enclosing sticks, by that the woody layer is put together.

original: yadājyam prokṣaṇyaḥ puroḍāśastenānnam pañcamīṣṭakāpyata evamu hāsyaiṣo
analyzed: yat ājyam prokṣaṇyaḥ puroḍāśaḥ tena annam pañcamī iṣṭakā apyate evam u ha asya eṣā
translated: Then in that there is ghee, sprinkling, and sacrificial cake, by that the fifth layer, food, is put together. Thus, then, this his

analyzed: gniḥ pañca iṣṭakaḥ sarvaḥ paśuḥ śva ārabdhaḥ bhavati
translated: fire, consisting of five layers, becomes all bound up in the victims.

analyzed: teṣām caturviṃśatiḥ sāmidhenyaḥ
translated: Of them there are twenty-four kindling-verses.

analyzed: caturviṃśati ardha māsaḥ vai saṃvatsaraḥ
translated: The year consists of twenty-four half-months; Agni is the year;

analyzed: gniḥ yāvān agniḥ yāvatī asya mātrā tāvatā eva enam etat saminddhe
translated: as great as Agni is, as great as is his measure, by so much he thus kindles him.

analyzed: yat u eva caturviṃśatiḥ
translated: And, again, as to why there are twenty-four.

analyzed: caturviṃśati akṣarā vai gāyatrī
translated: The Gayatri has twenty-four syllables; Agni is connected with the Gayatri;

analyzed: gniḥ yāvān agniḥ yāvatī asya mātrā tāvatā eva enam etat saminddhe  yat u eva caturviṃśatiḥ
translated: as great as Agni is, as great as is his measure, by so much he thus kindles him.

original: caturviṃśo vai puruśo daśa hastyā aṅgulayo daśa
analyzed: caturviṃśaḥ vai puruśas daśa hastyāḥ aṅgulayaḥ daśa
translated: And as to why there are twenty-four (kindling-verses),--a man is twenty-fourfold: ten fingers, ten toes,

original: pādyāścatvāryaṅgāni puruṣaḥ prajāpatiḥ prajāpatiragniryāvānagniryāvatyasya mātrā🔽tāvataivainametatsaminddhe / / /🔽ubhayīrgāyatrīśca triṣṭubhaścānvāha /🔽prāṇo gāyatryātmā triśṭupprāṇamevāsya🔽gāyatrībhiḥ saminddha ātmānaṃ triṣṭubbhirmadhye triṣṭubho bhavantyabhito🔽gāyatryo madhye hyayamātmābhitaḥ prāṇā bhūyasīḥ purastādgāyatrīranvāha
analyzed: pādyāḥ catvāri aṅgāni puruṣaḥ prajāpatiḥ prajāpatiḥ agniḥ yāvān agniḥ yāvatī asya mātrā  tāvatā eva enam etat saminddhe  ubhayīḥ gāyatrīḥ ca triṣṭubhaḥ ca anvāha  prāṇaḥ gāyatrī ātmā triśṭubh prāṇam eva asya  gāyatrībhiḥ saminddhe ātmānam triṣṭubbhiḥ madhye triṣṭubhaḥ bhavanti abhitas  gāyatryaḥ madhye hi ayam ātmā abhitas prāṇāḥ bhūyasīḥ purastāt gāyatrīḥ anvāha
translated: and four (parts) of the body; man is Pragâpati, and Pragâpati is Agni: as great as Agni is, as great as is his measure, by so much he thus kindles him.

analyzed: kanīyasīḥ upariṣṭāt bhūyāṃsaḥ hi ime purastāt prāṇāḥ kanīyāṃsaḥ upariṣṭāt
translated: He recites both Gayatri and Trishtubh verses;--the breath is of the nature of the Gayatri, and the body of the Trishtubh: by means of the Gayatri verses he kindles his breath, and by means of the Trishtubh verses his body. In the middle (of the kindling-verses) there are Trishtubh verses, and on both sides Gayatri verses; for this body is in the middle, and the vital airs are on both sides of it. In front he recites more Gayatri verses,🔽and fewer behind; for more are the vital airs in front, and fewer behind.

original: so 'nvāha / samāstvāgna ṛtavo vardhayantviti prajāpatiṃ visrastaṃ yatrāgniḥ
analyzed: saḥ nu āha samā astvā agne ṛtavaḥ vardhayantu iti prajāpatim visrastam yatra agniḥ
translated: He recites , 'May the seasons, O Agni, make thee even, make thee grow,'--whereby he means Pragâpati, disjointed (or, relaxed).

analyzed: samadadhāt tam abravīt yāḥ mad saṃmitāḥ sāmidhenyaḥ tābhiḥ mā samintsva iti
translated: To him who had thus prepared it he said, 'With those Sâmidhenî verses which are equal to me, equalise me!'

analyzed: saḥ etāḥ apaśyat
translated: He saw these (verses).

original: samāstvāgna ṛtavo vardhayantviti samāśca tvāgna ṛtavaśca
analyzed: samāḥ tvā agne ṛtavaḥ vardhayantu iti samāḥ ca tvā agne ṛtavaḥ ca
translated: 'May the equal seasons, O Agni, increase thee!'--equal and the seasons, O Agni,

original: vardhayantvityetatsaṃvatsarā ṛṣayo yāni satyeti saṃvatsarāśca tua 'rṣayaśca satyāni ca🔽vardhayantvityetatsaṃ divyena dīdihi rocanenetyasau vā ādityo divyaṃ rocanaṃ tena
analyzed: vardhayantu iti etat saṃvatsarāḥ ṛṣayaḥ yāni satyā iti saṃvatsarāḥ ca ṛṣayaḥ ca satyāni ca  vardhayantu iti etat sam divyena dīdihi rocanena iti asau vai ādityaḥ divyam rocanam tena
translated: increase thee!--'The Rishis, the year, and the truths!'--the Rishis, the year, and the truths,

original: saṃdīdihītyetadviśvā ābhāhi pradiśaścatasra iti sarvā ābhāhi pradiśaścatasra ityetat / / /
analyzed: saṃdīdihi iti etat viśvāḥ ābhāhi pradiśaḥ catasraḥ iti sarvāḥ ābhāhi pradiśaḥ catasraḥ iti etat
translated: increase thee!--'Shine thou with the heavenly light!'--the heavenly light, doubtless, is yonder sun: 'shine thou with that!'--'illumine thou all the four regions!'--that is, 'illumine thou all the four quarters.'

original: tā etā ekavyākhyānāḥ /🔽etamevābhi yathaitameva saṃskuryādetaṃ saṃdadhyādetaṃ
analyzed: tāḥ etāḥ eka vyākhyānāḥ  etam eva abhi yathā etam eva saṃskuryāt etam saṃdadhyāt etam
translated: These (verses) have one and the same explanation.

original: janayettā āgneyyaḥ prājāpatyā yadagnirapaśyattenāgneyyo yatprajāpatiṃ satainddha
analyzed: janayet tāḥ āgneyyaḥ prājāpatyāḥ yat agniḥ apaśyat tena āgneyyaḥ yat prajāpatim satā ainddha
translated: With them he should perform in such a way that he would make up that (fire-altar), that he would put it together, that he would produce it. They are sacred to Agni and Pragâpati: because Agni saw them, they are sacred to Agni; and because he kindled Pragâpati,

analyzed: tena prājāpatyāḥ
translated: they are sacred to Pragâpati.

analyzed: dvādaśa āpriyaḥ  dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaraḥ gniḥ yāvān agniḥ yāvatī asya
translated: The twelve-versed (hymn).

analyzed: mātrā tāvatā eva enam etat āprīṇāti
translated: The year consists of twelve months: as great as Agni is, as great as is his measure, by so much he thus gratifies him.

original: yadveva dvādaśa /🔽dvādaśākṣarā vai jagatīyaṃ vai jagatyasyāṃ hīdaṃ sarvaṃ🔽jagadiyamu vā agnirasyai hi sarvo 'gniścīyate yāvānagniryāvatyasya mātrā
analyzed: yat u eva dvādaśa  dvādaśa akṣarā vai jagatī iyam vai jagatī asyām hi idam sarvam  jagat iyam u vai agniḥ asyai hi sarvaḥ gniḥ cīyate yāvān agniḥ yāvatī asya mātrā
translated: And, again, as to why there are twelve.

analyzed: tāvatā eva enam etat āprīṇāti
translated: The Jagatî consists of twelve syllables, and this (earth) is the Jagatî, for on her all this moves (jati); and this (earth) is Agni, for in her all Agni is built up. As great as Agni is, as great as is his measure, with so much he thus gratifies him.

original: yadveva dvādaśa /🔽dvādaśākṣarā vai jagatī jagatī sarvāṇi candāṃsi sarvāṇi candāṃsi
analyzed: yat u eva dvādaśa  dvādaśa akṣarā vai jagatī jagatī sarvāṇi candāṃsi sarvāṇi candāṃsi
translated: And, again, as to why there are twelve.

original: prajāpatiḥ prajāpatiragniryāvānagniryāvatyasya mātrā tāvataivainametadāprīṇāti / / /🔽tā etā ūrdhvā asya samidho bhavantīti /🔽prajāpatiṃ visrastaṃ yatrāgnaḥ
analyzed: prajāpatiḥ prajāpatiḥ agniḥ yāvān agniḥ yāvatī asya mātrā tāvatā eva enam etat āprīṇāti  tāḥ etāḥ ūrdhvāḥ asya samidhaḥ bhavanti iti  prajāpatim visrastam yatra agnaḥ
translated: The Jagatî consists of twelve syllables, and the Jagatî is all the metres, and all the metres are Pragâpati, and Pragâpati is Agni. As great as Agni is, as great as is his measure, with so much he thus gratifies him.

original: samadadhāttamabravīdyā matsammitā āpriyastābhirmāprīṇīhīti / / /🔽sa etā aṣaśyat /🔽ūrdhvā asya samidho bhavantītyūrdhvā hyetasya samiddhasya🔽samidho bhavantyūrdhvā śukrā śocīṃṣyagnerityūrdhvāni hyetasya śukrāṇi
analyzed: samadadhāt tam abravīt yāḥ mad sammitāḥ āpriyaḥ tābhiḥ mā āprīṇīhi iti  saḥ etāḥ aṣaśyat  ūrdhvāḥ asya samidhaḥ bhavanti iti ūrdhvāḥ hi etasya samiddhasya  samidhaḥ bhavanti ūrdhvā śukrā śocīṃṣi agneḥ iti ūrdhvāni hi etasya śukrāṇi
translated: 'These are his upward kindling-sticks,' (with these words) he puts on the kindling-sticks; for when Pragâpati was relaxed, where they put Agni together, they said to him, 'Those (kindling-sticks) which are equal to us, do thou gratify thyself with them!'

original: śocīṃṣyarcīṃṣi bhavanti dyumattameti vīryavattametyetatsupratīkasyeti sarvato vā
analyzed: śocīṃṣi arcīṃṣi bhavanti dyumattamā iti vīryavattamā iti etat su pratīkasya iti sarvatas vā
translated: He saw these (verses), 'Upward his kindling-sticks are placed,'--for upward are placed the kindling-sticks of him (Agni) when he is kindled;--'upward his bright flames,'--for upward his bright flames and sparks go;--'of Agni, the most resplendent,'--that is, 'of him who is most powerful;'--'of the fair-formed,'--for he is indeed fair-formed on every side.

original: agniḥ supratīkaḥ sūnoriti yadenaṃ janayati tenāsyaiṣa sūnuḥ / / /

analyzed: tat āhuḥ yat yāvatyaḥ etasya agneḥ iṣṭakāḥ tāvanti kraye horātrāṇi sampadyante  yāni ūrdhvāni katham asya te lokāḥ anūpahitāḥ bhavanti iti yat vā  amāvāsyāyām dīkṣitvā amāvāsyāyām krīṇāti tat yāvantam eva lokam karoti tāvatīḥ iṣṭakāḥ  upadadhāti atha yāni ūrdhvāni krayādahāni tasmin avakāśe dhvaryuḥ agnim cinoti kva u  hi cinuyāt na ca saḥ vakāśaḥ syāt yāvanti vai saṃvatsarasya ahar rātrāṇi
translated: As to this they say, 'If the number of days from the purchase to the completion of the building of the fire-altar is the same as the number of days from the purchase to the new-moon day, then how are those days which are above the purchase to be added to the worlds (of the altar)?' Well, when one, having consecrated himself on the new-moon day, purchases (the Soma) on the new-moon day, then as much of the world as he builds he lays up so many bricks; and those days which are above the purchase, in that interval the Adhvaryu builds the fire-altar. For where else should he build it? There would be no room for it, were it not that as many days as there are in the year, so many bricks there are in the fire-altar.

original: etasyāgneriṣṭakā upa ca trayodaśo māsastrayodaśo vā eṣa māso yānyūrdhvāni🔽krayādahāni tadyā amūstrayodaśasya māsa iṣṭakāstābhirasya te lokā anūpahitā🔽bhavanti tatsamā lokāśceṣṭakāśca bhavanti / / /🔽etadvai yaiva prathamā paurṇamāsī /🔽tasyām paśumālabhate yā prathamāṣṭakā

translated: As to this they say, 'If the number of days from the purchase to the completion of the building of the fire-altar is the same as the number of days from the purchase to the completion of the year, then how are those days which are above the purchase to be added to the worlds (of the altar)?' Well, when one, having consecrated himself on the new-moon day, purchases (the Soma) on the new-moon day, then as great a world as he makes, so many bricks he lays down. Then in that interval of days which are above the purchase the Adhvaryu builds the fire-altar. For where indeed should he build it, if there were not that interval? As many days as there are in the year, so many are the bricks of this fire-altar, and the thirteenth month is (also) included therein. Now those days which are above the purchase are that thirteenth month. So those worlds of his are added to by those bricks of the thirteenth month. Thus the worlds and the bricks are equal in number.

analyzed: yuktena manasā vayam iti  manaḥ eva etat etasmai karmaṇe yuṅkte na hi uyuktena  manasā kim cana samprati śaknāti kartum devasya savituḥ save iti devena savitrā
translated: 'With a yoked mind we,'

analyzed: prasūtāḥ iti etat svargyāya śaktyā iti yathā etena karmaṇā svargam lokam iyāt evam etat āha

analyzed: śaktyā iti śaktyā hi svargam lokam eti

analyzed: yuktvāya savitā devān iti

analyzed: svargam ha enāṃlokam yatas dhiyā etasmai karmaṇe yuyuje bṛhat jyotiḥ kariṣyate iti asau  vai ādityaḥ bṛhat jyotiḥ eṣaḥ u eṣaḥ gniḥ etam u ete saṃskariṣyantaḥ bhavanti savitā

With that thunderbolt they drove away the Rakshas, the fiends, from the south, and in a place free from danger and injury they established this sacrifice.

original: yajñamatanvata tathaivaitadyajamāna etena vajreṇa dakṣiṇato rakṣāṃsi nāṣṭrā
analyzed: yajñam atanvata tathā eva etat yajamānaḥ etena vajreṇa dakṣiṇatas rakṣāṃsi nāṣṭrā
translated: In the same way the sacrificer, with this thunderbolt, drives away the Raksases, the evil spirits, on the south side,

original: apahatyābhaye 'nāṣṭrā etaṃ yajñaṃ tanute / / /🔽dakṣiṇata āhavanīyo bhavati /🔽uttarata eṣābhrirupaśete vṛṣā vā āhavanīyo
analyzed: apahatya abhaye nāṣṭrāḥ etam yajñam tanute  dakṣiṇatas āhavanīyaḥ bhavati  uttaratas eṣā abhriḥ upaśete vṛṣā vai āhavanīyaḥ
translated: and performs this sacrifice in a place free from danger and injury.🔽The Ahavaniya fire is on the south side,🔽and the lump of clay lies on the north side. The Ahavaniya fire is the male,

analyzed: yoṣā abhriḥ dakṣiṇatas vai vṛṣā yoṣām upaśete ratni mātre ratni mātrāt hi vṛṣā  yoṣām upaśete
translated: and the lump of clay is the female. The male lies on the south side of the female. At a distance of a cubit,🔽for at a distance of a cubit the male lies by the female.

original: sā vaiṇavī syāt /🔽agnirdevebhya udakrāmatsa veṇum prāviśattasmātsa suṣiraḥ sa etāni
analyzed: sā vaiṇavī syāt  agniḥ devebhyaḥ udakrāmat sa veṇum prāviśat tasmāt sa suṣiraḥ saḥ etāni
translated: It should be of bamboo.

analyzed: varmāṇi abhitas kuruta parvāṇi an anuprajñānāya yatra yatra nidadāha tāni  kalmāṣāṇi abhavan
translated: Agni went away from the gods. He entered the bamboo. Therefore it is hollow. He made these coverings around it, the joints, to prevent its being known. Wherever it burned,🔽those became mottled.

analyzed: sā kalmāṣī syāt
translated: It should be mottled.

original: sā hyāgneyī yadi kalmāṣīṃ na vindedapyakalmāṣī syātsuṣirā tu🔽syātsaivāgneyī saiṣā yoniragneryadveṇuragniriyam mṛnna vai yonirgarbhaṃ
analyzed: sā hi āgneyī yadi kalmāṣīm na vindet api akalmāṣī syāt suṣirā tu  syāt sā eva āgneyī sā eṣā yoniḥ agneḥ yat veṇuḥ agniḥ iyam mṛd na vai yoniḥ garbham
translated: For that is of Agni. If he cannot find a mottled one, it may be unmottled, but it must be hollow.

original: hinastyahiṃsāyai yonervai jāyamāno jāyate yonerjāyamāno jāyātā iti / / /
analyzed: hinasti ahiṃsāyai yoneḥ vai jāyamānaḥ jāyate yoneḥ jāyamānaḥ jāyātai iti
translated: That is of Agni. This is Agni's birthplace, namely the bamboo. Agni is this earth. The birthplace does not injure the embryo. For one is born from the birthplace. 'May he be born from the birthplace,' (with this hope they offer).

analyzed: prādaśa mātrī syāt
translated: It should be a cubit long.

analyzed: prādeśa mātram hi idam abhi vāc vadati aratni mātrī tu eva bhavati
translated: For this (fire-pan) is spoken of as a span in extent, and yet it is only an arm's length.

original: bāhurvā aratnirbāhuno vai vīryaṃ kriyate vīryasammitaiva tadbhavati / / /
analyzed: bāhuḥ vai aratniḥ bāhunaḥ vai vīryam kriyate vīrya sammitā eva tat bhavati
translated: The arm is an arm's length, and strength is performed by the arm: it thus becomes commensurate with strength.

analyzed: anyataḥkṣṇut syāt
translated: It should have a hole on one side.

analyzed: anyatararaḥ hi idam vācaḥ kṣṇutam ubhayataḥkṣṇut tu eva
translated: For this (earth) is a hole on one side only; but it should have a hole on both sides,

original: bhavatyubhayato hīdaṃ vācaḥ kṣṇutaṃ yadenayā daivaṃ ca vadati mānuṣaṃ cātho🔽yatsatyaṃ cānṛtaṃ ca tasmādubhayataḥkṣṇut / / /🔽yadvevobhayataḥkṣṇut /
analyzed: bhavati ubhayatas hi idam vācaḥ kṣṇutam yat enayā daivam ca vadati mānuṣam ca atho  yat satyam ca anṛtam ca tasmāt ubhayataḥkṣṇut  yat u eva ubhayataḥkṣṇut
translated: for this (earth) is a hole on both sides, in that by it one speaks to the gods and to men, and also🔽to what is true and what is untrue: therefore it should have a hole on both sides.🔽And, again, as to why it has a hole on both sides.

analyzed: atas vai abhreḥ vīryam yatas syai
translated: From that side of the cloud whence its hole (is seen),

analyzed: eva asyām etat vīryam dadhāti
translated: from that side he thus lays strength into it.

original: yadvevobhayataḥkṣṇut /🔽etadvā enaṃ devā anuvidyaibhyo lokebhyo🔽'khanastathaivainamayametadanuvidyaibhyo lokebhyaḥ khanati / / /
analyzed: yat u eva ubhayataḥkṣṇut  etat vai enam devāḥ anuvidya ebhyaḥ lokebhyaḥ  khanaḥ tathā eva enam ayam etat anuvidya ebhyaḥ lokebhyaḥ khanati
translated: And, again, as to why it has a hole on both sides.

analyzed: sa yat iti khanati  tat enam asmāt lokāt khanati atha yat ūrdhvā uccarati
translated: The gods, having discovered him (Agni), dug him out from these worlds; and in like manner does this (Sacrificer), having discovered him, now dig him out from these worlds.🔽When he digs with 'Him,' he digs him out from this world; and when he moves upwards,

analyzed: tat amuṣmāt lokāt atha yat antareṇa saṃcarati tat antarikṣa lokāt sarvebhyaḥ
translated: he digs him out from yonder world; and when he moves about in the middle, he digs him out from the air-world. From all the worlds.

analyzed: eva enam etat ebhyaḥ lokebhyaḥ khanati
translated: He digs it out from these worlds.

original: tāmādatte / devasya tvā savituḥ prasave 'śvinorbāhubhyām vitṛprasūta🔽evaināmetadetābhirdevatābhirādatte gāyatreṇapūṣṇo hastābhyāmādade gāyatreṇa🔽candasāṅgirasvaditi sa candasātho asyāṃ gāyatraṃ cando dadhāti pṛthivyāḥ
analyzed: tām ādatte devasya tvā savituḥ prasave śvinoḥ bāhubhyām vitṛ prasūta  eva enām etat etābhiḥ devatābhiḥ ādatte gāyatreṇa pūṣṇaḥ hastābhyām ādade gāyatreṇa  candasā aṅgirasvat iti sa candasā atha u asyām gāyatram candaḥ dadhāti pṛthivyāḥ
translated: He takes it up. 'In the impulse of the god Savitr, with the arms of the Asvins, with the hands of Pusan, I take thee', (with these words) he takes it up.🔽He takes it up with these deities. 'With the Gayatri verse, with the arms of Pusan, I take thee, with the Gayatri metre, O Angiras!'

original: sadhasthādagnim purīṣyamaṅgirasvadābhareti paśavo vai purīṣam pṛthivyā
analyzed: sadhasthāt agnim purīṣyam aṅgirasvat ābhara iti paśavaḥ vai purīṣam pṛthivyā
translated: With the Gayatri metre he takes it up, and puts the Gayatri metre into it. 'From the abode of the earth I take Agni, the domestic, O Angiras!'

analyzed: upasthāt agnim paśavyam agni vat ābhara iti etat traiṣṭubhena candasā aṅgirasvat iti
translated: 'From the abode of the earth I take Agni, the domestic, like Agni!' he says. 'With the Tristubh metre, O Angiras!'

original: tadenāṃ traiṣṭubhena candasādatte 'tho asyāṃ traiṣṭubhaṃ cando dadhāti / / /
analyzed: tat enām traiṣṭubhena candasā ādatte thaḥ u asyām traiṣṭubham candaḥ dadhāti
translated: With the Tristubh metre he takes it up, and puts the Tristubh metre into it.

original: abhrirasīti /🔽abhrirhyeṣā tadenaṃ satyenādatte nāryasīti vajro vā abhriryoṣā nārī na
analyzed: abhriḥ asi iti  abhriḥ hi eṣā tat enam satyena ādatte nārī asi iti vajraḥ vai abhriḥ yoṣā nārī na
translated: 'Thou art the hoe', (with these words) he takes it up.🔽The hoe is indeed this (earth), therefore he takes it up with the truth. 'Thou art the woman', (with these words) he takes it up. The hoe is indeed the thunderbolt, the woman is the female,

original: vai yoṣā kaṃ cana hinasti śamayatyevaināmetadahiṃsāyai tvayā vayamagniṃ śakema
analyzed: vai yoṣā kam cana hinasti śamayati eva enām etat ahiṃsāyai tvayā vayam agnim śakema
translated: the female does not injure any one, he thereby appeases it, for harmlessness. 'With thee we may obtain Agni', (with these words) he takes it up.

original: khanituṃ sadhastha etīdaṃ vai sadhasthaṃ tvayā vayamagniṃ śakema🔽khanitumasmintsadhastha ityetajjāgatena candasāṅgirasvaditi tadenāṃ jāgatena
analyzed: khanitum sadhasthaḥ eti idam vai sadhastham tvayā vayam agnim śakema  khanitum asmin sadhasthe iti etat jāgatena candasā aṅgirasvat iti tat enām jāgatena
translated: 'He goes to dig the place of meeting',--the place of meeting, doubtless, is this (earth): 'by thee we shall be able to dig Agni here,' this is what he thereby says;--'in the place of meeting, with the Jagatî metre, O Aṅgiras!'--he thus digs it out with the Jagatî metre, with the Gayatra (hymn-metre);--'with the Jagatî metre, O Aṅgiras!'--he thus digs it out with the Jagatî metre, with the Trishtubh (hymn-metre);--'with the Jagatî metre, O Aṅgiras!'--he thus digs it out with the Jagatî metre, with the Gagatî (hymn-metre).

analyzed: candasā ādatte thaḥ asyām jāgatam candaḥ dadhāti
translated: 'He goes to dig in the place of rest',--the place of rest, doubtless, is this (earth): 'by thee we shall be able to dig Agni here, in this place of rest,' this is what he thereby says.--'With the Gagatî metre, Aṅgiras-like!'--he thus takes it up with the Gagatî metre; and he bestows the Gagatî metre on this (earth).

analyzed: tribhiḥ ādatte
translated: With three (verses) he takes it up;

original: trivṛdagniryāvānagniryāvatyasya mātrā tāvataivaināmetadādatte🔽tribhirādāyāthaināṃ caturthenābhimantrayata etadvā enāṃ devāstribhirādāyāthāsyāṃ🔽caturthena vīryamadadhustathaivaināmayametattribhirādāyāthāsyāṃ caturthena
analyzed: trivṛt agniḥ yāvān agniḥ yāvatī asya mātrā tāvatā eva enām etat ādatte  tribhiḥ ādāya atha enām caturthena abhimantrayate etat vai enām devāḥ tribhiḥ ādāya atha asyām  caturthena vīryam adadhuḥ tathā eva enām ayam etat tribhiḥ ādāya atha asyām caturthena
translated: for Agni is threefold: as great as Agni is, as great as is his measure, by so much he thus takes it up.

original: vīryaṃ dadhāti / / /🔽hasta ādhāya saviteti /🔽haste hyasyāhitā bhavati bibhradabhrimiti bibharti hyenāṃ🔽hiraṇyayīmiti hiraṇmayī hyeṣā yā🔽candomayyagnerjyotirnicāyyetyagnerjyotirdṛṣṭvetyetatpṛthivyā adhyābharaditi
analyzed: vīryam dadhāti  haste ādhāya savitā iti  haste hi asya āhitā bhavati bibhrat abhrim iti bibharti hi enām  hiraṇyayīm iti hiraṇmayī hi eṣā yā  candaḥ mayi agneḥ jyotiḥ nicāyya iti agneḥ jyotiḥ dṛṣṭvā iti etat pṛthivyāḥ adhyābharat iti
translated: Having taken it up with three (verses), he then addresses it with a fourth; for the gods, having taken it up with three (verses), then bestowed vigour on it with a fourth; and in like manner does this (Sacrificer), now, having taken it up with three (verses), then bestow vigour on it with a fourth.

analyzed: pṛthivyai hi enat adhi ābharati ānuṣṭubhena candasā aṅgirasvat iti
translated: 'Having laid hold of it with the hand, O Savitri,'--for it is laid hold of with the hand;--'bearing the tawny (cow),' for he does bear it;--'the golden (cow),' for it is indeed golden which is made of the metres;--'having beheld the light of Agni,'--that is, 'having beheld the light of Agni;'--'he has brought it from the earth,'--for from the earth he indeed brings it;--'with the Anushtubh metre, Aṅgiras-like!'--

original: tadenāmānuṣṭubhena candasādatte 'tho asyāmānuṣṭubhaṃ cando dadhāti🔽tānyetānyeva candāṃsyeṣābhrirārambhāyaiveyaṃ vaiṇavī kriyate / / /
analyzed: tat enām ānuṣṭubhena candasā ādatte tha u asyām ānuṣṭubham candaḥ dadhāti  tāni etāni eva candāṃsi eṣā abhriḥ ārambhāya eva iyam vaiṇavī kriyate
translated: He takes it with the Anushtubh metre; he thus bestows on it the Anushtubh metre.🔽These metres are these (bricks); this (brick) of reed is made for the beginning.

original: tāṃ haike hiraṇmayīṃ kurvanti /🔽hiraṇyayīti vā abhyukteti na tathā kuryādyadvā eṣā
analyzed: tām ha eke hiraṇmayīm kurvanti  hiraṇyayī iti vai abhyuktā iti na tathā kuryāt yat vai eṣā
translated: Some make it of gold,🔽saying, 'Gold is indeed said to be immortal;

analyzed: candāṃsi tena eṣā hiraṇyam amṛtam hiraṇyam amṛtāni candāṃsi
translated: but let him not do so; in that it is (made of) the metres, it is gold; gold is immortal; the metres are immortal.

analyzed: tām caturbhiḥ ādatte  catur akṣarā vai sarvā vāc vāc iti ekam akṣaram akṣaram iti
translated: He takes it with four (verses);🔽for the whole speech consists of four syllables; 'speech' is one syllable, 'syllable' is three syllables.

analyzed: tri akṣaram tat yat tat vāc iti ekam akṣaram yā eva eṣā anuṣṭubh uttamā sā sā atha
translated: That one syllable 'speech' is this very Anushtubh which is the last;

original: yadakṣaramiti tryakṣarametāni tāni pūrvāṇi yajūṃṣi sarvayaivaitadvācāgniṃ khanati
analyzed: yat akṣaram iti tri akṣaram etāni tāni pūrvāṇi yajūṃṣi sarvayā eva etat vācā agnim khanati
translated: and that which is the three syllables 'syllable' are those former Yagus-formulas. With the whole speech he digs the fire-altar;

analyzed: sarvayā vācā sambharati tasmāt caturbhiḥ
translated: with the whole speech he prepares (the altar); therefore with four (verses).

original: yadveva caturbhiḥ /🔽catasro vai diśaścatasṛṣu taddikṣu vācaṃ dadhāti tasmāccatasṛṣu
analyzed: yat u eva caturbhiḥ  catasraḥ vai diśaḥ catasṛṣu tat dikṣu vācam dadhāti tasmāt catasṛṣu
translated: And again why with four.

original: dikṣu vāgvadati candobhiśca yajurbhiścādatte tadaṣṭau catasro diśaścatasro
analyzed: dikṣu vāc vadati candobhiḥ ca yajurbhiḥ ca ādatte tat aṣṭau catasraḥ diśaḥ catasraḥ
translated: There are four quarters; in the four quarters he lays speech (Vâk); therefore speech speaks in the four quarters. With the metres and the Yagus-formulas he takes it; that makes eight; the quarters are four,

original: 'vāntaradiśaḥ sarvāsu taddikṣu vācaṃ dadhāti tasmātsarvāsu dikṣu vāgvadati / / /
analyzed: vā antara diśaḥ sarvāsu tat dikṣu vācam dadhāti tasmāt sarvāsu dikṣu vāc vadati
translated: He places speech in all the intermediate directions, or in those directions; therefore speech speaks in all the directions.

analyzed: haste eṣā abhriḥ bhavati atha paśūn abhimantrayate
translated: He then recites over the animals.

analyzed: etat vai eṣu devāḥ anveṣiṣyantaḥ
translated: The gods, seeking to find them,🔽placed strength in front of them; in the same way he, seeking to find them, places strength in front of them.

analyzed: purastāt vīryam adadhuḥ tathā eva eṣu ayam etat anveṣiṣyan purastāt vīryam dadhāti  saḥ śvam abhimantrayate  praturtam vājin ādrava iti yat vai kṣipram tat tūrtam atha
translated: He recites over the horse,🔽'Run swiftly, O steed!' What is swift, that is 'turt';

analyzed: yat kṣiprāt kṣepīyaḥ tat pratūrta variṣṭhām anu saṃvatam iti iyam vai variṣṭhā
translated: but what is swifter than swift, that is 'pratura'. 'Follow the widest course', the widest course is this (earth),

original: saṃvadimāmanu saṃvatamityetaddivi te janma paramamantarikṣe tava nābhiḥ
analyzed: saṃvat imām anu saṃvatam iti etat divi te janma paramam antarikṣe tava nābhiḥ
translated: 'follow the course' means this (earth). 'Your highest birth is in the sky, your navel in the atmosphere,

original: pṛthivyāmadhi yoniriditi tadenametā devatāḥ karotyagniṃ vāyumādityaṃ tadaśve
analyzed: pṛthivyām adhi yoniḥ id iti tat enam etāḥ devatāḥ karoti agnim vāyum ādityam tat aśve
translated: your womb and birthplace are on the earth', he thereby makes it (the horse) these deities, Agni, Vâyu, Âditya;

analyzed: vīryam dadhāti
translated: he thus bestows strength on the horse.

analyzed: atha rāsabham
translated: He then recites over the ass,

analyzed: yuñjāthām rāsabham yuvam iti adhvaryum ca etat yajamānam
translated: 'Yoke the ass, O ye two', he says to the Adhvaryu and the sacrificer;

analyzed: ca āha asmin yāme vṛṣaṇvasū iti asmin karmaṇi vṛṣaṇvasū iti etat agnim
translated: 'in this race, O ye rich in treasure', in this rite, O ye rich in treasure, this is what he means; 'Agni and Soma', he says;

analyzed: bharantam asmayum iti agnim bharantam asmad preṣitam iti etat tat rāsabhe vīryam
translated: 'Bearing the one who is friendly to us',--Agni, he bears who is sent by us, that is, 'him';--that is the strength in the ass.

analyzed: dadhāti
translated: 'Bearing us', (he says), that is, 'sent by us'; he thus bestows strength on the ass.

original: athājam / yogeyoge tavastaraṃ vājevāje havāmaha ityannaṃ vai vājaḥ
analyzed: atha ajam yoge yoge tavastaram vāje vāje havāmahe iti annam vai vājaḥ
translated: Now the goat. 'In every need we invoke thee, in every race for booty', booty means food;

analyzed: karmaṇi karmaṇi tavastaram anne nne havāmahe iti etat sakhāyaḥ indram ūtaya
translated: 'in every rite we invoke thee, in every race for food', he says; 'friends, Indra, for help',

analyzed: iti indriyavantam ūtaye iti etat tat aje vīryam dadhāti
translated: that is, 'possessing power, for help'; he thus bestows strength on the goat.

analyzed: tribhiḥ abhimantrayate
translated: With three (verses) he addresses (the animals);

analyzed: trivṛt agniḥ yāvān agniḥ yāvatī asya mātrā
translated: Agni is threefold, as great as Agni is, as great as is his measure,

analyzed: tāvatā eva eṣu etat vīryam dadhāti
translated: with so much he thus bestows strength on them.

analyzed: atha enān prācaḥ utkramayati  tat enam etaiḥ paśubhiḥ anvicati na upaspṛśati agniḥ eṣa
translated: He then makes them step forward to the east;

analyzed: yat paśavaḥ na id mā ayam agniḥ hinasat iti
translated: he thus seeks him (Agni) with these animals. He does not touch (the animals); for Agni is that (fire), and the animals are this (earth); lest he should injure this (earth) by Agni.

analyzed: sā u śvam utkramayati  pratūrvan ehi avakrāman aśastīḥ eti pāpmā vai aśastiḥ tvaramāṇa
translated: He makes the horse step forward;

analyzed: ehi avakrāman pāpmānam iti etat rudrasya gāṇapatyam mayobhūḥ ehi iti raudrāḥ vai
translated: 'Striding, come hither, treading down the enemies', the enemies are evil; 'striding, come hither, treading down evil', he says; 'the lordship of Rudra's host, come hither, bringing bliss', the goats are connected with Rudra;

original: paśavo yā te devatā tasyai gāṇapatyam mayobhūrehītyetattadenamaśvenānvicati / / /
analyzed: paśavaḥ yā te devatā tasyai gāṇapatyam mayobhūḥ ehi iti etat tat enam aśvena anvicati
translated: 'The animal which is thy deity, to that deity, to the lord of the herd, go thou, being full of sap,'--this is what he thereby says to him; and he thus searches for him by means of the horse.

original: atha rāsabham /🔽urvantarikṣaṃ vīhi svastigavyūtirabhayāni kṛṇvanniti yathaiva
analyzed: atha rāsabham  uru antarikṣam vīhi svasti gavyūtiḥ abhayāni kṛṇvan iti yathā eva
translated: Then (he searches for him) by means of the ass.

original: yajustathā bandhuḥ pūṣṇā sayujā sahetīyaṃ vai pūṣānayā sayujā sahetyetattadenaṃ
analyzed: yajuḥ tathā bandhuḥ pūṣṇā sayujā saha iti iyam vai pūṣā ayā sayujā saha iti etat tat enam
translated: 'Go thou to the wide air, bestowing security and prosperity, and making (us) fearless,'--as the text, so the meaning;--'with Pûshan, thy fellow-traveller,'--Pûshan doubtless is this (earth): 'with her, thy fellow-traveller,' this is what he thereby says; and he thus searches for him by means of the ass.

analyzed: rāsabhena anvicati  atha ajam pṛthivyāḥ sadhasthāt agnim purīṣyam aṅgirasvat ābhara iti pṛthivyā
translated: Then (he searches for him) by means of the he-goat.

analyzed: upasthāt agnim paśavyam agni vat ābhara iti etat tat enam ajena anvicati
translated: 'From the abode of earth, O Agni, the domestic, I take thee, as one belonging to Aṅgiras,'--that is, 'from the abode of the earth I take thee, O domestic Agni, as one belonging to Agni;' and he thus searches for him by means of the he-goat.

analyzed: tribhiḥ anvicati

translated: 'Thou art the son of Pushya', he says; 'thou art the son of cattle', he says; 'the supporter of all', he says; for he supports all this (universe). original: athainam parigṛhṇāti /🔽abhryā ca dakṣiṇato hastena ca hastenaivottaratastvāmagne
analyzed: atha enam parigṛhṇāti  abhryā ca dakṣiṇatas hastena ca hastena eva uttaratas tvām agne
translated: he does this very thing.

original: puṣkarādadhyatharvā niramanthatetyāpo vai puṣkaram prāṇo 'tharvā prāṇo vā🔽etamagre 'dbhyo niramanthanmūrdhno viśvasya vāghata ityasya sarvasya mūrdhna
analyzed: puṣkarāt adhi atharvā niramanthata iti āpaḥ vai puṣkaram prāṇaḥ tharvā prāṇaḥ vā  etam agre dbhyaḥ niramanthan mūrdhnaḥ viśvasya vāghataḥ iti asya sarvasya mūrdhnaḥ
translated: He then encloses him (the fire) on the south side with the horn and the hand, on the north side with the hand only. 'Atharvan from the lotus-leaf rubbed thee into life, O Agni', he says; the lotus-leaf is the waters, Atharvan is the breath;🔽he rubbed him into life from the waters. 'From the head of all that moves', he says;

analyzed: iti etat
translated: from the head of all this (universe), he means to say.

analyzed: tam u tvā dadhyaṅ ṛṣiḥ
translated: 'Thee, O Agni, the sage Dadhyañc,

original: putra īdhe atharvaṇa iti vāgvai dadhyaṅṅātharvaṇaḥ sa enaṃ
analyzed: putraḥ īdhe atharvaṇaḥ iti vāc vai dadhyaṅ ātharvaṇaḥ saḥ enam
translated: the son of Atharvan, kindled', he says; Dadhyañc of Atharvan is speech, and he kindled him.

original: tata ainddha vṛtrahaṇam puraṃdaramiti pāpmā vai vṛtraḥ pāpmahanam
analyzed: tatas ainddha vṛtra haṇam puraṃdaram iti pāpmā vai vṛtraḥ pāpma hanam
translated: 'The slayer of Vrtra, the storm-god', he says; Vrtra is evil, the slayer of evil,

analyzed: puraṃdaram iti etat
translated: the storm-god, he means to say.

analyzed: tam u tvā pāthyaḥ vṛṣā
translated: 'Thee, O Agni, the sage Dadhyañc,🔽the son of Atharvan, kindled', he says; Dadhyañc of Atharvan is speech, and he kindled him.🔽'The slayer of Vrtra, the storm-god', he says; Vrtra is evil, the slayer of evil,🔽the storm-god, he means to say.

original: samīdhe dasyuhantamamiti mano vai pāthyo vṛṣā sa enaṃ
analyzed: samīdhe dasyu hantamam iti manaḥ vai pāthyaḥ vṛṣā saḥ enam
translated: 'Enkindling the best slayer of the Dasyus,'--the Paushya bull, doubtless, is the mind; he (Agni) kindled him

original: tata ainddha dhanaṃjayaṃ raṇeraṇa iti yathaiva yajustathā bandhuḥ / / /
analyzed: tatas ainddha dhanaṃjayam raṇeraṇaḥ iti yathā eva yajuḥ tathā bandhuḥ
translated: 'the victorious in battle after battle,'--as the text, so the meaning.

original: gāyatrībhiḥ /🔽prāṇo gāyatrī prāṇamevāsminnetaddadhāti nnetaddadhāti tāsāṃ nava
analyzed: gāyatrībhiḥ  prāṇaḥ gāyatrī prāṇam eva asmin etat dadhāti n etat dadhāti tāsām nava
translated: With Gâyatrî verses.

original: padāni nava vai prāṇāḥ saptatisṛbhistrayo vai prāṇāḥ prāṇa udāno vyānastānevāsmi
analyzed: padāni nava vai prāṇāḥ saptatisṛbhiḥ trayaḥ vai prāṇāḥ prāṇaḥ udānaḥ vyānaḥ tān eva asmi
translated: The Gâyatrî is the breath: he thus lays breath into him (Agni). Of these (verses) there are nine feet; for there are nine breaths in man, and with seventy-three (verses) there are three breaths, to wit, the out-breathing, the up-breathing, and the through-breathing: these he thus lays into him.

analyzed: śīrṣan avāñcaḥ dvau tān eva asmin etat dadhāti
translated: The two (verses) at the beginning have nine feet, and the two at the end have nine feet: these he thus lays into him as the head.

original: athaite triṣṭubhā uttare bhavataḥ /🔽ātmā vai triṣṭubātmānamevāsyaitābhyāṃ🔽saṃskaroti sīda hota sva u loke cikitvānityagnirvai hotā tasyaiṣa svo loko🔽yatkṛṣṇājinaṃ cikitvāniti vidvānityetatsādayā yajñaṃ sukṛtasya yonāviti kṛṣṇājinaṃ vai
analyzed: atha ete triṣṭubhau uttare bhavataḥ  ātmā vai triṣṭubh ātmānam eva asya etābhyām  saṃskaroti sīda hota sve u loke cikitvān iti agniḥ vai hotā tasya eṣa svaḥ lokaḥ  yat kṛṣṇājinam cikitvān iti vidvān iti etat sādaya yajñam sukṛtasya yonau iti kṛṣṇājinam vai
translated: Now, those two subsequent (verses) are Trishtubh ones.

analyzed: kukṛtasya yoniḥ devāvīḥ devān haviṣā yajāsi iti devaḥ san devān avan haviṣā
translated: The Trishtubh is the body: by means of these two he puts the body together. 'Sit thou down, O Hotar, in thine own place, O thou that knowest!' the Hotar, doubtless, is Agni, and this is his own place, to wit, the black antelope skin;--'O thou that knowest!' that is, 'the wise one;'--'settle the sacrifice in the womb of good action!' the womb of good action, doubtless, is the black antelope skin;--'with the gods, worship the gods with sacrificial food!' the gods, doubtless, are the vital airs: thus, 'with the vital airs worship the vital airs with sacrificial food!'

original: yajāsītyetadagne bṛhadyajamāne vayo dhā iti yajamānāyāśiṣamāśāste / / /
analyzed: yajāsi iti etat agne bṛhat yajamāne vayaḥ dhāḥ iti yajamānāya āśiṣam āśāste
translated: 'Thou art sacrificing', this is 'sacrifice'; 'O Agni, bestow great life on the sacrificer', he invokes a blessing on the sacrificer.

analyzed: ni hotā hotṛṣadane vidānaḥ iti
translated: 'The Hotri, the known one, in the Hotri's seat',

original: agnirvai hotā kṛṣṇājinaṃ hotṛṣadanaṃ vidāna iti
analyzed: agniḥ vai hotā kṛṣṇājinam hotṛṣadanam vidānaḥ iti
translated: Agni is the Hotri, the black antelope skin is the Hotri's seat, the known one,

original: vidvānityetattveṣo dīdivāṃ asadatsudakṣa iti tveṣo dīpyamāno 'sadatsudakṣa
analyzed: vidvān iti etat tveṣaḥ dīdivān asadat su dakṣaḥ iti tveṣaḥ dīpyamānaḥ sadat su dakṣa
translated: 'the knowing one', this is it. 'The radiant one has sat down, the well-powerful one', the radiant one has sat down, the well-powerful one,

analyzed: iti etat adabdha vrata pramatiḥ vasiṣṭhaḥ iti adabdha vrata pramatiḥ hi eṣa vasiṣṭhaḥ
translated: this is it. 'The one with unbroken vow, the best', the one with unbroken vow, the best,

original: sahasrambharaḥ śucijthvo agniriti sarvaṃ vai sahasraṃ sarvambharaḥ śucijihvo
analyzed: sahasrambharaḥ śucijthvaḥ agniḥ iti sarvam vai sahasram sarvambharaḥ śuci jihvaḥ
translated: 'the thousand-bearing, pure-tongued Agni', the thousand is everything, the thousand-bearing one is the pure-tongued one,

analyzed: gniḥ iti etat dvābhyām āgneyībhyām triṣṭubbhyām tasya uktaḥ bandhuḥ
translated: Agni, this is it. With two (verses) addressed to Agni, in the Triṣṭubh (metre), the significance of that has been explained.

original: athaiṣā bṛhatyuttamā bhavati /🔽bṛhatīṃ vā eṣa saṃcito 'bhisampadyate yādṛgvai
analyzed: atha eṣā bṛhatī uttamā bhavati  bṛhatīm vai eṣa saṃcitaḥ abhisampadyate yādṛś vai
translated: Now this is the last Brhati (verse).

original: yonau retaḥ sicyate tādṛgjāyate tadyadetāmatra bṛhatīṃ karoti tasmādeṣa saṃcito
analyzed: yonau retaḥ sicyate tādṛś jāyate tat yat etām atra bṛhatīm karoti tasmāt eṣa saṃcitaḥ
translated: This (fire-altar) when built up becomes the Brhati (metre); for such as is the seed which is infused into the womb, such is (the child) that is born. In that he makes this (altar) here the Brhati (metre), therefore this (altar) when built up

analyzed: bṛhatīm abhisampadyate
translated: becomes the Brhati (metre).

analyzed: saṃsīdasva mahān asi iti
translated: 'Sit down, thou art great', (with these words) he puts down the naturally-perforated (brick);

original: idamevaitadretaḥ siktaṃ saṃsādayati tasmādyonau retaḥ🔽siktaṃ saṃsīdati śocasva devavītama iti dīpyasva devavītama ityetadvi dhūmamagne
analyzed: idam eva etat retaḥ siktam saṃsādayati tasmāt yonau retaḥ  siktam saṃsīdati śocasva deva vītamaḥ iti dīpyasva deva vītamaḥ iti etat vi dhūma magne
translated: He thus settles this seed which has been sprinkled; therefore the seed which is sprinkled in the womb settles. 'Glow, O Agni, for the feast of the gods', (with the words), 'shine, O Agni, for the feast of the gods', he means to say.

original: aruṣam miyedhya sṛja praśasta darśatamiti yadā vā eṣa samidhyate 'thaiṣa
analyzed: aruṣam miyedhya sṛja praśasta darśatam iti yadā vai eṣa samidhyate tha eṣa
translated: He thus settles this seed which has been shed; therefore the seed which is shed in the womb settles. 'Shine, O God-adoring one', he says; that is, 'blaze, O God-adoring one'. 'Send forth the ruddy smoke, O meet for sacrifice, O praised, O most visible', for when he is kindled

original: dhūmamaruṣaṃ visṛjate darśatamiti dadṛśa iva hyeṣaḥ / / /
analyzed: dhūmam aruṣam visṛjate darśatam iti dadṛśe iva hi eṣaḥ
translated: he sends forth the ruddy smoke, the most visible. 'Visible', (he says), for he is as if seen.

analyzed: tāḥ ṣaḍ sampadyante  ṣat ṛtavaḥ saṃvatsaraḥ saṃvatsaraḥ gniḥ yāvān agniḥ yāvatī asya
translated: They make up six.

analyzed: mātrā tāvat tat bhavati yat u eva saṃvatsaram abhisampadyate
translated: Six seasons are a year, the year is Agni: as great as Agni is, as great as is his measure, so great does this become. And in that it makes up the year,

original: tadbṛhatīmabhisampadyate bṛhatī hi saṃvatsaro dvādaśa paurṇamāsyo dvādaśāṣṭakā
analyzed: tat bṛhatīm abhisampadyate bṛhatī hi saṃvatsaraḥ dvādaśa paurṇamāsyaḥ dvādaśa aṣṭakā
translated: it makes up the Brihatî, for the year is the Brihatî. Twelve are the full moons, twelve the Ashtakâs,

analyzed: dvādaśa amāvāsyāḥ tat ṣaṭtriṃśat ṣaṭtriṃśat akṣarā bṛhatī tam dakṣiṇatas udañcam āharati
translated: twelve the new moons; that makes thirty-six; the Brihatî has thirty-six syllables. He brings it (the fire) from the south to the north;

original: dakṣiṇato vā udagyonau retaḥ sicyata eṣo asyaitarhi yoniravicedamāharati retaso
analyzed: dakṣiṇatas vai udak yonau retaḥ sicyate eṣaḥ asya etarhi yoniḥ a vicā idam āharati retasaḥ
translated: from the south, namely, the seed is shed into the womb from above. This is now his womb. He brings it without stumbling,

analyzed: vicedāya
translated: without letting the seed be spilt.

analyzed: atha tatra apaḥ upaninayati
translated: He then puts it down there.

analyzed: yat vai asyai kṣatam yat viliṣṭam adbhiḥ vai tat saṃdhīyate
translated: Whatever is injured or broken in it is healed by water.

analyzed: dbhiḥ eva asyai etat kṣatam viliṣṭam saṃtanoti saṃdadhāti
translated: By water he heals, joins, that which is injured or broken in it.

original: apo devīrupasṛja /🔽madhumatīrayakṣmāya prajābhya iti raso vai madhu
analyzed: apaḥ devīḥ upasṛja  madhumatīḥ ayakṣmāya prajābhyaḥ iti rasaḥ vai madhu
translated: 'Let the divine waters flow together',🔽'rich in honey, for the people without disease', he says; honey means sap;

analyzed: rasavatīḥ a yakṣma tvāya prajābhyaḥ iti etat tāsām āsthānāt ujjihatām oṣadhayaḥ su pippalā
translated: 'rich in sap, for the people without disease', he says; 'from their place let the plants shoot forth, with good berries',

analyzed: iti apām vai āsthānāt ujjihate oṣadhayaḥ su pippalāḥ
translated: from the place of the waters the plants shoot forth with good berries.

original: athaināṃ vāyunā saṃdadhāti /🔽yadvā asyai kṣataṃ yadviliṣṭaṃ vāyunā vai
analyzed: atha enām vāyunā saṃdadhāti  yat vai asyai kṣatam yat viliṣṭam vāyunā vai
translated: He then joins it with the wind.🔽Whatever is injured or broken in it is healed by the wind.

original: tatsaṃdhīyate vāyunaivāsyā etatkṣataṃ viliṣṭaṃ saṃtanoti saṃdadhāti / / /
analyzed: tat saṃdhīyate vāyunā eva asyai etat kṣatam viliṣṭam saṃtanoti saṃdadhāti
translated: By the wind he heals, joins, that which is injured or broken in it.

analyzed: sam te vāyuḥ mātariśvā dadhātu iti
translated: 'Let the wind Matariśvan join thee',

original: ayaṃ vai vāyurmātariśvā yo 'yam pavata uttānāyā🔽hṛdayaṃ yadvikastamityuttānāyā hyasyā etaddhṛdayaṃ vikastaṃ yo devānāṃ carasi
analyzed: ayam vai vāyuḥ mātariśvā yaḥ yam pavate uttānāyā  hṛdayam yat vikastam iti uttānāyāḥ hi asyāḥ etat hṛdayam vikastam yaḥ devānām carasi
translated: this wind Matariśvan which blows here, 'the heart of the extended',🔽for the heart of this (earth) is extended when it is extended, 'thou who goest with the gods on thy way',

original: prāṇathenetyeṣa hi sarveṣāṃ devānāṃ carati prāṇathena kasmai deva vaṣaḍastu
analyzed: prāṇathena iti eṣa hi sarveṣām devānām carati prāṇathena kasmai deva vaṣaṭ astu
translated: he goes on his way with the gods, 'to whom, O god, will the Vasat cry come?'

original: tubhyamiti prajāpatirvai kastasmā evaitadimāṃ vaṣaṭkaroti no haitāvatyanyāhutirasti
analyzed: tubhyam iti prajāpatiḥ vai kaḥ tasmai eva etat imām vaṣaṭkaroti na u ha etāvatī anyā āhutiḥ asti
translated: To thee,'--for he who says 'to thee' is Prajapati: to him he makes this Vasat-call; for there is no other oblation so great as this one.

original: yathaiṣā / / /🔽athaināṃ digbhiḥ saṃdadhāti /🔽yadvā asyai kṣataṃ yadviliṣṭaṃ digbhirvai🔽tatsaṃdhīyate digbhirevāsyā etatkṣataṃ viliṣṭaṃ saṃtanoti saṃdadhāti sa imāṃ cemāṃ
analyzed: yathā eṣā  atha enām digbhiḥ saṃdadhāti  yat vai asyai kṣatam yat viliṣṭam digbhiḥ vai  tat saṃdhīyate digbhiḥ eva asyai etat kṣatam viliṣṭam saṃtanoti saṃdadhāti saḥ imām ca imām
translated: And as to why he makes this Vasat-call, it is because he thereby makes this (earth) to be his own.

original: ca diśau saṃdadhāti tasmādete diśau saṃhite athemāṃ cemāṃ ca tasmādvevaite saṃhite
analyzed: ca diśau saṃdadhāti tasmāt ete diśau saṃhite atha imām ca imām ca tasmāt u eva ete saṃhite
translated: He then joins it (the earth) with the regions. What part of it is injured, what part is broken, that he thereby joins with the regions; and with the regions he thus heals and joins what part of it is injured and broken. He joins this and that region: hence these two regions are joined together. And this and this: hence these two are also joined together.

original: ityagre 'theti athetyatheti taddakṣiṇāvṛttaddhi devatrānayānayā vai bheṣajaṃ kriyate
analyzed: iti agre tha iti atha iti atha iti tat dakṣiṇa āvṛt tat hi devatrā anayā anayā vai bheṣajam kriyate
translated: 'Athâtha,'--thus (he says) at first, and then 'athâtha,'--thus (he says) afterwards. Thus (he says) in a southerly direction, for that (leads) to the gods. By this (direction) healing is done:

analyzed: naya eva enām etat bhiṣajyati
translated: by this (direction) he thus heals it.

original: atha kṛṣṇājinaṃ ca puṣkaraparṇaṃ ca samudgṛhṇāti /🔽yonirvai puṣkaraparṇaṃ yonyā🔽tadretaḥ siktaṃ samudgṛhṇāti tasmādyonyā retaḥ siktaṃ samudgṛhyate sujāto jyotiṣā
analyzed: atha kṛṣṇājinam ca puṣkara parṇam ca samudgṛhṇāti  yoniḥ vai puṣkaraparṇam yonyā  tat retaḥ siktam samudgṛhṇāti tasmāt yonyāḥ retaḥ siktam samudgṛhyate su jātaḥ jyotiṣā
translated: He then takes up the black antelope skin and the lotus-leaf. The lotus-leaf is the womb:

original: saha śarma varūthamāsadatsvariti sujāto hyeṣa jyotiṣā saha śarma caitadvarūthaṃ ca
analyzed: saha śarma varūtham āsadat svar iti su jātaḥ hi eṣa jyotiṣā saha śarma ca etat varūtham ca
translated: in the womb he thus takes up the infused seed; whence the infused seed is taken up in the womb. 'Well-born, with the light, he hath sat down to protection and shelter,'--for he (Agni) is indeed well-born, and with the light he has sat down to this protection and shelter;--'the son of the waters, the child of the streams,'--for he (Agni) is indeed the son of the waters, the child of the streams;--'the pure one, the purifier,'--for he is indeed pure and a purifier;--'the golden-handed hath sat down on the back of the earth,'--for he (Agni) is indeed golden-handed, and he sits down on the back of the earth.

analyzed: svar ca āsīdati
translated: And he has become his own.

analyzed: atha enam upanahyati
translated: Then he ties it (to the post).

original: yonau tadreto yunakti tasmādyonau reto yuktaṃ na niṣpadyate
analyzed: yonau tat retaḥ yunakti tasmāt yonau retaḥ yuktam na niṣpadyate
translated: He joins the seed to the womb; therefore the seed joined to the womb is not lost.

original: yoktreṇa yoktreṇa hi yogyaṃ yuñjanti mauñjena trivṛtā tasyokto bandhuḥ / / /
analyzed: yoktreṇa yoktreṇa hi yogyam yuñjanti mauñjena trivṛtā tasya uktaḥ bandhuḥ
translated: With a yoke-halter, for with a yoke-halter they yoke what is to be yoked. With one of Muñja grass, threefold; the significance of this has been explained.

original: tatparyasyati /🔽vāso agne viśvarūpaṃ saṃvyayasva vibhāvasaviti varuṇyā vai yajñe
analyzed: tat paryasyati  vāsaḥ agne viśva rūpam saṃvyayasva vibhāvaso iti varuṇyā vai yajñe
translated: He turns it round.

analyzed: rajjuḥ avaruṇyam eva enat etat kṛtvā yathā vāsaḥ paridhāpayet evam paridhāpayati
translated: 'Put on, O Agni, the garment of many forms, O thou of various splendour,'--for the rope is connected with Varuna;--'the unseizeable,'--for that (rope) he has made unseizeable by Varuna, as it were;--'put it on, as it were, a garment,'--thus he makes him put it on.

original: athainamādāyottiṣṭhati /🔽asau vā āditya eṣo 'gniramu tadādityamutthāpayatyudu🔽tiṣṭha svadhvaretyadhvaro vai yajña udu tiṣṭha suyajñiyetyetadavā no devyā dhiyeti🔽yā te daivī dhīstayā no 'vetyetaddūśe ca bhāsā bṛhatā suśukvaniriti darśanāya ca🔽bhāsā bṛhatā suśukvanirityetadāgne yāhi suśastibhiriti ye voḍhāraste suśastaya āgne
analyzed: atha enam ādāya uttiṣṭhati  asau vai ādityaḥ eṣaḥ gniḥ amu tat ādityam utthāpayati udu  tiṣṭha su adhvara iti adhvaraḥ vai yajñaḥ udu tiṣṭha su yajñiya iti etat ava naḥ devyā dhiyā iti  yā te daivī dhīḥ tayā naḥ vā iti etat dūśe ca bhāsā bṛhatā suśukvaniḥ iti darśanāya ca  bhāsā bṛhatā su śukvaniḥ iti etat ā agne yāhi su śastibhiḥ iti ye voḍhāraḥ te su śastayaḥ ā agne
translated: Having taken it up, he rises up.

analyzed: yāhi voḍhṛbhiḥ iti etat
translated: That Agni is yonder sun: he thus raises yonder sun. 'Rise up, O thou of the sacrifice!'--the sacrifice, doubtless, is the sacrifice: 'rise up, O thou of the good sacrifice!' he thereby says. 'With the divine thought, O god,'--that is, 'with that divine thought of thine, come thou to us!'--'to the fair light, O thou of fair light!'--that is, 'to the sight, O thou of fair light!'--'Come, O Agni, with the fair praises!'--those who carry (the chariot) are the fair praises: 'come, O Agni, with the carriers!' he thereby says.

analyzed: atha enam itas ūrdhvam prāñcam pragṛhṇāti
translated: He then lifts it up from him (the Âhavanîya fire) and turns it towards the east.

analyzed: asau vai ādityaḥ eṣaḥ gniḥ amum
translated: Now that Agni is yonder sun;

original: tadādityamita ūrdhvam prāñcaṃ dadhāti tasmādasāvāditya ita ūrdhvaḥ prāṅ dhīyata🔽ūrdhva ū ṣu ṇa ūtaye tiṣṭhā devo na saviteti yathaiva yajustathā bandhurūrdhvo
analyzed: tat ādityam itas ūrdhvam prāñcam dadhāti tasmāt asau ādityaḥ itas ūrdhvaḥ prāṅ dhīyata  ūrdhvaḥ u su naḥ ūtaye tiṣṭha devaḥ na savitā iti yathā eva yajuḥ tathā bandhuḥ ūrdhvaḥ
translated: he thus places yonder sun above and in front of him: hence yonder sun is placed above and in front of this (earth).

original: vājasya sanitetyūrdhvo vā eṣa tiṣṭhanvājamannaṃ sanoti
analyzed: vājasya sanitā iti ūrdhvaḥ vai eṣa tiṣṭhan vājam annam sanoti
translated: 'Rise up for help, O god Savitar!'--as the text, so the meaning;--'rise up for the winning of strength!'--for rising up he indeed wins strength, food.

original: yadañjibhirvāghadbhirvihvayāmaha iti raśmayo vā etasyāñjayo vāghatastānetadāha
analyzed: yat añjibhiḥ vāghadbhiḥ vihvayāmahe iti raśmayaḥ vai etasya añjayaḥ vāghataḥ tān etat āha
translated: 'In that we invoke with anointed priests,'--his rays are indeed anointed priests: it is them he means.

original: parobāhu pragṛhṇāti parobāhu hyeṣa ito 'thainamupāvaharati🔽tamupāvahṛtyoparinābhi dhārayati tasyopari bandhuḥ / / /
analyzed: parobāhu pragṛhṇāti parobāhu hi eṣaḥ itas tha enam upāvaharati  tam upāvahṛtya uparinābhi dhārayati tasya upari bandhuḥ
translated: He holds it up with the right (hand), for it is with the right (hand) that he (the sun) is here (above). He then lowers it;🔽and having lowered it, he holds it over his navel: the significance of this (will be explained) farther on.

analyzed: haste eṣa bhavati atha paśūn abhimantrayate
translated: It (the fire) is now his (the sacrificer's) hand; he then addresses the animals.

analyzed: etat vai eṣu devāḥ sambhariṣyantaḥ  purastāt vīryam adadhuḥ tathā eva eṣu ayam etat sambhariṣyan purastāt vīryam dadhāti
translated: For the gods, when about to create these (animals),🔽put vigour into them in front; and in like manner does this (Sacrificer), when about to create them, now put vigour into them in front.

analyzed: saḥ śvam abhimantrayate
translated: He addresses the horse.

original: sa jāto garbho asi rodasyoritīte vai dyāvāpṛthivī rodasī🔽tayoreṣa jāto garbho 'gne cārurvibhṛta oṣadhīṣviti sarvāsu hyeṣa cārurvibhṛta🔽oṣadhiṣu citraḥ śiśuḥ pari tamāṃsyaktūniti citro vā eṣa śiśuḥ pareṇa🔽tamāṃsyaktūnatirocate pra mātṛbhyo adhi kanikradadgā ityoṣadhayo vā etasya
analyzed: sa jātaḥ garbhaḥ asi rodasyoḥ iti ite vai dyāvāpṛthivī rodasī  tayoḥ eṣa jātaḥ garbhaḥ gne cāruḥ vibhṛtaḥ oṣadhīṣu iti sarvāsu hi eṣa cāruḥ vibhṛta  oṣadhiṣu citraḥ śiśuḥ pari tamāṃsi aktūn iti citraḥ vai eṣa śiśuḥ pareṇa  tamāṃsi aktūn atirocate pra mātṛbhyaḥ adhi kanikradat gāḥ iti oṣadhayaḥ vai etasya
translated: 'Thou art born as the embryo of the two worlds,'--the two worlds, doubtless, are heaven and earth;--'of them thou art born as the embryo,'--that is, 'of these two thou art born as the embryo;'--'agreeable, O Agni, distributed among the plants,'--for he (the sun) is indeed distributed among all plants in an agreeable form;--'the variegated child hath overcome the dark regions,'--for this variegated child indeed overcomes the dark regions;--'crying aloud thou hast gone forth from thy mothers,'--the plants, doubtless, are his (Agni's) mothers, for from them he is born.

original: mātarastābhya eṣa kanikradatpraiti tadaśve vīryaṃ dadhāti / / /
analyzed: mātaraḥ tābhyaḥ eṣa kanikradat praiti tat aśve vīryam dadhāti
translated: 'Thou art born as the embryo of the two worlds,'--the two worlds, doubtless, are heaven and earth;--'thou, O Agni, the lovely one, art distributed among the plants,'--for he (Agni) is indeed distributed as the lovely one among all plants;--'the variegated child hath overcome the dark regions,'--variegated, doubtless, is he (Agni), and a child, and he indeed overcomes the dark regions;--'crying aloud thou hast gone forth from thy mothers,'--his mothers, doubtless, are the plants, and from them he (Agni) goes forth crying aloud: he thus bestows vigour on the horse.

original: atha rāsabham /🔽sthiro bhava vīḍvaṅga āśurbhava vājyarvanniti sthiraśca bhava
analyzed: atha rāsabham  sthiraḥ bhava vīḍu aṅgaḥ āśuḥ bhava vājī arvan iti sthiraḥ ca bhava
translated: Now the ass.

original: vīḍvaṅgaścāśuśca bhava vājī cārvannityetatpṛthurbhava suṣadastvamagneḥ🔽purīṣavāhaṇa iti pṛthurbhava suśīmastvamagneḥ paśavyavāhana ityetattadrāsabhe🔽vīryaṃ dadhāti / / /
analyzed: vīḍu aṅgaḥ ca āśuḥ ca bhava vājī cārvan iti etat pṛthuḥ bhava suṣadaḥ tvam agneḥ  purīṣavāhaṇaḥ iti pṛthuḥ bhava suśīmaḥ tvam agneḥ paśavya vāhanaḥ iti etat tat rāsabhe  vīryam dadhāti
translated: 'Be firm, O thou of firm limbs! be swift, O steed, O courser!'--that is, 'be firm, and of firm limbs, and swift, and a courser!'--'be broad, O thou of fair abode, O Agni's bearer of dung!'--that is, 'be broad, O thou of fair abode, O Agni's bearer of dung!'--he thus bestows vigour on the ass.🔽Now the he-goat.

original: athājam / śikhā bhava prajābhyo mānuṣībhyastvamaṅgira ityaṅgirā vā agnirāgneyo
analyzed: atha ajam śikhā bhava prajābhyaḥ mānuṣībhyaḥ tvam aṅgiraḥ iti aṅgirāḥ vai agniḥ āgneyaḥ
translated: 'Be a crest, O thou of human kind, for men!'--Agni is a kind of Angiras;--'the bearer of the oblation, O thou of fair abode, O Agni's bearer of dung!'--that is, 'be a crest, O thou of fair abode, for men, the bearer of the oblation, O Agni's bearer of dung!'--he thus bestows vigour on the he-goat.

analyzed: jaḥ śamayati eva enam etat ahiṃsāyai mā dyāvāpṛthivī abhiśocīḥ mā antarikṣam mā
translated: 'The unborn one pacifies him, for the sake of non-injury. Do not burn the heaven and earth, do not burn the atmosphere,

original: vanaspatīnityetatsarvam mā hiṃsīrityetattadaje vīryaṃ dadhāti / / /🔽tribhirabhimantrayate /🔽trivṛdagniryāvānagniryāvatyasya mātrā tāvataivaiṣvetadvīrya
analyzed: vanaspatīn iti etat sarvam mā hiṃsīḥ iti etat tat aje vīryam dadhāti  tribhiḥ abhimantrayate  trivṛt agniḥ yāvān agniḥ yāvatī asya mātrā tāvatā eva eṣu etat vīrya
translated: 'The unborn one pacifies him, for the sake of harmlessness; do not burn the sky and the earth, nor the atmosphere, nor the trees,'--that is, 'do not injure anything here;'--he thus bestows vigour upon the unborn one.

analyzed: dadhāti
translated: With three (verses) he addresses (the fire);--threefold is Agni: as great as Agni is, as great as is his measure, by so much he thus bestows vigour upon them.

analyzed: atha enam eteṣām paśūnām upariṣṭāt pragṛhṇāti
translated: He then takes it up above those animals;

original: tadenametaiḥ paśubhiḥ sambharati🔽nopaspṛśati vajro vai paśavo reta idaṃ nedidaṃ reto vajreṇa hinasānītyatho agnirayam
analyzed: tat enam etaiḥ paśubhiḥ sambharati  na upaspṛśati vajraḥ vai paśavaḥ retaḥ idam na id idam retaḥ vajreṇa hinasāni iti atha u agniḥ ayam
translated: he thus equips it with those animals.

analyzed: paśavaḥ ime na id ayam agniḥ imān paśūn hinasat iti
translated: He does not touch it, lest he should injure this seed with the thunderbolt, for animals are the thunderbolt, and this (fire) is seed; or lest this Agni should injure these animals.

original: tamaśvasyopariṣṭātpragṛhṇāti /🔽praitu vājī kanikradaditi praitu vājī kanikradyamāna
analyzed: tam aśvasya upariṣṭāt pragṛhṇāti  praitu vājī kanikradat iti praitu vājī kanikradyamāna
translated: He takes it up above the horse;

original: ityetannānadadrāsabhaḥ patveti tadaśvasya yajuṣi rāsabhaṃ nirāha tadrāsabhe śucaṃ
analyzed: iti etat nānadat rāsabhaḥ patvā iti tat aśvasya yajuṣi rāsabham nirāha tat rāsabhe śucam
translated: 'Let the strong one go forth neighing,'--that is, 'let the strong one go forth neighing;'--'the ass braying after him,'--he thereby puts sorrow into the ass; in the horse's formula he mentions the ass: he thus puts sorrow into the ass.

original: dadhāti bharannagnim purīṣyam mā pādyāyuṣaḥ pureti bharannagnim paśavya mo
analyzed: dadhāti bharan agnim purīṣyam mā pādi āyuṣaḥ purā iti bharan agnim paśavya mā
translated: 'Bearing Agni, the lord of the people, do not go away before the end of life,'--bearing Agni, the lord of cattle, do not go away before the end of life.

analyzed: asmāt karmaṇaḥ purā pādi iti etat tat enam aśvena sambharati
translated: 'From this work he has stepped forth in the beginning,'--that is, 'he has stepped forth in the beginning from this work;'--with the horse he thus supplies him (Agni).

original: atha rāsabhasya /🔽vṛṣāgniṃ vṛṣaṇam bharanniti vṛṣā vā agnirvṛṣā rāsabhaḥ sa vṛṣā
analyzed: atha rāsabhasya  vṛṣā agnim vṛṣaṇam bharan iti vṛṣā vai agniḥ vṛṣā rāsabhaḥ sa vṛṣā
translated: Now with the ass.

original: vṛṣāṇam bharatyapāṃ garbhaṃ samudriyamityapāṃ hyeṣa garbhaḥ🔽samudriyastadenaṃ rāsabhena sambharati / / /
analyzed: vṛṣāṇam bharati apām garbham samudriyam iti apām hi eṣa garbhaḥ  samudriyaḥ tat enam rāsabhena sambharati
translated: 'Bearing the male, the male Agni,'--the male, indeed, is Agni, and the male is also the ass: he thus bears the male, the male (Agni);--'the ocean-born child of the waters,'--for he (the ocean) is indeed the child of the waters, the ocean-born: with the ass he thus supplies him (Agni).

original: athāpādatte /🔽agna āyāhi vītaya ityavitava ityetattadenam brahmaṇā
analyzed: atha apādatte  agne āyāhi vītaye iti avitave iti etat tat enam brahmaṇā
translated: He then takes hold of him (Agni).

analyzed: yajuṣā etasmāt caudrāt varṇāt apādatte  atha ajasya ṛtam satyam ṛtam satyam iti ayam vai agniḥ ṛtam asau ādityaḥ satyam yadi
translated: 'Come hither, O Agni, for the banquet,'--that is, 'for the unbanqueting;'--with the Brahman (prayer), with the Yagus (formula) he thus takes hold of him from that violent (sudden) colour.🔽Now with the goat.

analyzed: vāsau ṛta mayam satyam ubhayam vetat ayam agniḥ tasmāt āha ṛtam satyam ṛtam satyam iti

analyzed: tat enam ajena sambharati  tribhiḥ sambharati  trivṛt agniḥ yāvān agniḥ yāvatī asya mātrā
translated: With the goat he thus supplies him (Agni).

With three (verses) he addresses (Agni) in front: that makes six; the significance of this has been explained .

analyzed: atha etān paśūn āvartayanti
translated: They then lead up those victims.

translated: 'I bear him who is to be borne, like Agni, the lord of cattle', he says; that is, he equips him with the man who is not slain.

analyzed: agnim ādadhati sikatāḥ upakīrṇāḥ bhavanti tāsām upari bandhuḥ
